Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Self-Assembly Processing through Architecturally- and Compositionally-Complex Block Copolymer Surfactant Mixtures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to elucidate the interconnected links between the design of architecturally-complex block copolymers, their integration into nanoscale structures, their dynamics in solution and kinetics of self-assembly at solid-fluid interfaces. In so doing, this research will advance self-assembly processing as a means of nano-manufacturing. A distinctive and novel aspect of the work involves the use of kinetic modeling to quantify the relative importance of thermodynamically-controlled and mass transport-governed relaxation processes that operate during self-assembly at solid-fluid interfaces. Experimental studies will focus on the effect of variations in composition and architecture, which will be introduced by systematically mixing diverse sets of well-defined copolymers based on polystyrene/polyisoprene and polystyrene/poly(2-vinylpyridine) block copolymers, which display surfactant-like behaviors and self-organize in selective solvents. The shape, size, and kinetics of assembly of the mixed copolymer aggregates will be fully characterized. Understanding how variations in the composition and architecture of the constituent building blocks will pave the way for using mixtures of simpler building blocks to create complex, higher-order structures, and also help to identify new and useful pathways for tailoring thin film formation by self-assembly.

The spontaneous generation of nanostructures from simpler polymeric building blocks is fundamental to a wide variety of technologies finding application in society, including drug encapsulation and delivery, environmental remediation by solubilization and mobilization of contaminants, and formation of patterned surfaces for microelectronics and bit-patterned media. This research promises to provide new insights into how to design and process copolymer-based materials to attain assemblies of different shape, size, and properties, thereby spurring additional technological advances. In addition, knowledge of the kinetics of assembly in solution and at interfaces will enhance the development of self-assembly as form of nano-manufacturing, which offers intriguing possibilities for creating new products, structures and devices via an efficient and scalable method. Finally, this research program will foster the development of young scientists, engineers and teachers, and the greater scientific community will be engaged through a symposium conducted at a national meeting.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Block copolymers dissolved in solution often are able to organize into structures that incorporate tens or hundreds of individual molecules, creating aggregates having sizes in the range of 10-100 nanometers. This process, which is known as self-assembly, proceeds spontaneously and without external intervention, is routinely used by nature to create complex and elegant structures with properties that surpass most human-made systems. Inspired by the potential to create useful building blocks through self-assembly processing, the focus of this project was to investigate how co-assembly of block copolymers of different topological design impacts the structure and stability of aggregates formed. This was accomplished through systematic studies involving a variety of different copolymer designs, including multi-block, star-like and comb-like copolymers. New and unusual nanoscale aggregates were generated by co-assembly, and links between copolymer design, processing protocol, and nanoscale structure were elucidated through a variety of modern, state-of-the-art characterization techniques sensitive to nanoscale structure. In addition, useful protocols enabling polymeric structures to be directly imaged in volatile solvents were developed. The fundamental insights describing how self-assembly processing can be used to generate new and interesting nanoscale and mesoscale structures from block copolymer mixtures may impact a variety applications of these systems. This includes the development of sensors or biomedical products based on patterned surfaces or three-dimensional structures, or assemblies used for environmental remediation.

This project helped to teach and train several young scientists and engineers, including two graduate students who are now independent scientists, and four undergraduate students. Of these four undergraduates, one went to professional (medical school), one is pursuing graduate studies, and two intend to pursue graduate studies after completing their undergraduate engineering degrees.  All of the students involved in the project gained skills in synthesis and characterization of polymeric materials and processing by self-assembly. Findings from research have been shared through journal publications and via presentations, especially by students, at national, regional and local conferences. Students and faculty involved in this project have impacted a numerous young learners through outreach activities, serving as role models, mentors, and teachers.  For example, one graduate student participated in a Project Literacy initiative that nurtures and inspires children from disadvantages backgrounds, the principal investigator developed and gave guest lectures in middle school science classes, and members of the team volunteered as mentors in a summer science camp offered at the university that is aimed at middle school students. Thus, in addition to contributing new knowledge in the emerging area of nanomanufacturing of polymeric materials and training graduate and undergraduate students for eventual technological leadership, this project has fostered the development of students at a variety of ages through outreach and service.


Last Modified: 12/20/2016
Modified by: S. Michael Kilbey
